titlestmt.titleproper: Kaiser Wilhelm Institute lantern slide collection
titlestmt.subtitle: Kaiser Wilhelm Institute lantern slide collection

titlepage.titleproper: Kaiser Wilhelm Institute lantern slide collection

did.unittitle: Kaiser Wilhelm Institute lantern slide collection

scopecontent.p: The collection of lantern slides and boxes is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the boxes were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: Rassengutachen: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Personlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

controlaccess.subject: Eugenics--Germany.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: Rassengutachen: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Personlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

controlaccess.subject: Eugenics--Germany.
controlaccess.corpname: Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Anthropologie, menschliche Erblehre und Eugenik.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: Rassengutachen: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Personlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

Titled boxes: Rassengutachen: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Personlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: Rassengutachen: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Personlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: vertical orientation; 4 frames, two top images of girl with short dark hair; two bottom images of girl with long dark hair in two braids; both girls face front and right and wear large white round collars

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.

Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slide was probably used for teaching purposes. The slide contains information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the slide from being disposed.

physdesc.physfacet: materials inside boxes: Glass lantern slide.; film; paper tape; black and white photographs Boxes of approx. 18-53 old glass plate positive or negative slides in each box. Titled boxes: 1-Rassengutachten: 43 black and white slides, 22 black and white photos; images of people, physical characteristics, maps. 2-Bastarde, Rheinland: 2 slides, 1 negative of people; other photos showing charts, and people of different racial backgrounds. 3-Vorlesungen; Charakter u. Persönlichkeit: 31 negatives/slides; charts and graphs on character and personality traits as well as statistics corresponding to slides. 4-Familienanthropologie: slides of diagrams of family lineages and slides of individuals; 13 photos of individuals. A detailed handwritten log by Dr. Otmar von Verschuer (among others) accompanies the slides.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Gift of Irmgard Nippert

scopecontent.p: The lantern slide box is from the holdings of the former Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin. This Institute for anthropology and genetics was one of many centers used for the study of eugenics during the Third Reich. Aside from ordering sterilization and other eugenic "procedures," medical experiments originating in euthenasia killing centers and concentration camps were also evaluated at the Institute. Such names as Von Verschuer, Fischer, and Mengele are associated with the Institute. The slides contained in the box were probably used for teaching purposes. The slides contained information used to back up so-called eugenic and racial theories prevalent during the Third Reich. The Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin was disbanded after World War II. In 1952, the Institute for Human Genetics at the University of Muenster was founded and appointed Dr. Otmar Von Verschuer as its director; as the former director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, he brought with him a large number of books and materials. An employee of the Institute, Dr. Irmgard Nippert, saved the boxes and slides from being disposed.
